subject: probability
title: Independence of Events
contentHtml: In probability theory, two events are said to be independent if the occurrence or non-occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other event.
problemHtml: Consider two events: flipping a fair coin and rolling a six-sided die. Are these events independent?
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the events", "mathHtml": "\[E_1 = \text{heads}, E_2 = \text{die roll is even}\]", "explanation": "We need to clearly define what we mean by 'independent'."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the joint probability", "mathHtml": "\[P(E_1 \cap E_2) = P(\text{heads} \cap \text{even})\]", "explanation": "We'll calculate the probability of both events occurring together."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the individual probabilities", "mathHtml": "\[P(E_1) = P(\text{heads}), P(E_2) = P(\text{even})\]", "explanation": "We'll also calculate the probability of each event occurring individually."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Check for independence", "mathHtml": "\[P(E_1 \cap E_2) = P(E_1) \cdot P(E_2)\]", "explanation": "If the joint probability equals the product of individual probabilities, then the events are independent."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Verify the result", "mathHtml": "\[P(\text{heads} \cap \text{even}) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{6} = \frac{3}{12}\]", "explanation": "Let's plug in some numbers to see if our calculation checks out."} ],
intuition: Independence means that the occurrence of one event does not change the probability of the other event.

subject: probability
title: Independence of Events
contentHtml: In probability theory, two events are independent if the occurrence or non-occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other event.

workedExample.problemHtml: Let's test whether two coin tosses are independent. We have a fair coin with P(head) = 0.5 and P(tail) = 0.5. We want to know if the outcome of the first toss affects the probability of getting heads or tails on the second toss.

steps.mathHtml: \[E_1: \text{heads on the first toss}, E_2: \text{heads on the second toss}\]
steps.explanation: We define two events: getting heads or tails on the first and second coin tosses.

steps.description: Find the probability of each event
steps.explanation: The probability of getting heads or tails on either coin toss is 0.5.
The joint probability of getting heads on both coin tosses is the product of the individual probabilities.
The conditional probability of getting heads on the second toss given that we got heads on the first toss is still 0.5.

steps.description: Check if the events are independent
steps.explanation: Since the conditional probability of getting heads on the second toss given that we got heads on the first toss is equal to the unconditional probability, the events are independent.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The two coin tosses are independent.

intuition: Independence means that knowing the outcome of one event doesn't change our understanding of the other event.
